news.headline: There’s no jobs report today. Here’s what it might’ve shown.
news.summary: The government shutdown has delayed two consecutive job reports from the Labor Department. That means the most recent comprehensive picture of the state of the labor market is from August, when data showed a 4.3% unemployment rate.
news.article_text:
How was the job market in October?

Don’t look to the government to answer that question right now.

The shutdown of the federal government — now the longest-running in US history — has delayed two consecutive job reports from the Labor Department. October’s should’ve been released today, while September’s was originally scheduled for release on Oct. 3

news.headline: Fed’s Jefferson supported last week’s rate cut, but wants to move slowly on further cuts
news.summary: Federal Reserve Vice Chair Philip Jefferson said he supported cutting rates at the last policy meeting. But he wants to move more slowly going forward on future rate cuts. Jefferson joined a growing chorus of Fed officials who are undecided whether to cut rates again in December.
news.article_text:
Federal Reserve Vice Chair Philip Jefferson said Friday that he supported cutting rates at the last policy meeting, given greater concerns about the job market, but he wants to move more slowly going forward on future rate cuts.

“The current policy stance is still somewhat restrictive, but we have moved it closer to its neutral level that neither restricts nor stimulates the economy,” Jefferson said in a speech at the Bundesbank in Frankfurt, Germany. “Given this, it makes sense to proceed slow

news.summary: Federal Reserve officials had to make their latest interest-rate decision without key economic statistics. The data they will receive when the government reopens probably won’t make the next decision any easier.
news.article_text:
Federal Reserve officials had to make their latest interest-rate decision without key economic statistics thanks to the US government shutdown. The data they will receive when the government reopens probably won’t make the next decision any easier.

news.headline: Working from home hurting business travel, says British Airways owner
news.summary: Workers in the UK log on from home two days a week. This is holding back a recovery in business travel at BA. Volume of corporate bookings with BA this year is running at just 63pc of the level seen before Covid.
news.article_text:
Working from home is hitting demand for business travel in the UK, according to the parent company of British Airways (BA).

Luis Gallego, the chief executive of International Airlines Group (IAG), said the propensity for British workers to log on from home two days a week was holding back a recovery in business travel at BA.

He said: “The situation is improving, but slowly and with very different performance in the different airlines.

news.headline: BA Owner IAG Says Sales Hurt by Weak Transatlantic Route
news.summary: IAG says transatlantic routes experienced weakness in the third quarter. Revenue from North Atlantic routes fell 7.1%, partly triggered by foreign exchange impacts.
news.article_text: British Airways parent IAG said its transatlantic routes experienced weakness in the third quarter, weighing on earnings that missed estimates. The company reported total revenue of 9.33 billion ($10.8 billion), compared with Bloomberg analyst estimates of 9.43 billion. Revenue from North Atlantic routes fell 7.1%, partly triggered by foreign exchange impacts as well as what it called "some softness" in that segment. Bloomberg's Benedikt Kammel reports.

news.headline: Compared to Estimates, Brown & Brown (BRO) Q3 Earnings: A Look at Key Metrics

news.article_text:

news.headline: SpaceX Buys More EchoStar Spectrum to Boost Mobile Ambitions
news.summary: SpaceX agreed to buy an additional $2.6 billion in spectrum licenses from EchoStar, building on the $17 billion worth of licenses that it agreed to buy earlier this year.  The spectrum purchases give Elon Musk’s rocket and satellite-internet company an expanded foothold in the mobile-phone business and will give EchoStar a SpaceX stake that tops $11 billion at the rocket company's current share price.  SpaceX provides home broadband service through its Starlink business and has dipped into the mobile-phone sector through a U.S. partnership with T-Mobile.
